Once done with this, you will have to search through that forum for a guide or a method or a ROM developed by some enthusiast for your device and then install it.I hope this helps you.

If you own a Samsung phone, First download your kitkat firmware from SamMobile then google and download Samsung usb driver, Odin software for the firmware update. Very simple. Go to Settings - > About Phone and tap on the ‘System Update’ or ‘Software Update’ option. You need a working internet plan to check whether there’s an update. The phone then connects with the company’s website and lets you know whether you have an update. In case, there’s no authentic update, you can manually root your smartphone and install a custom ROM. Check out this wikiHow article on how to do that: 3 Ways to Manually Upgrade an Android Device Operating System Thanks for the A2A. Cheers :)

It entirely depends on the phone you are using. For a premium smartphone, you will most likely get an update. Otherwise for the mid segment smartphones, there are very rare chances that the vendor will provide update to us. All new Android releases requires a lot of porting, testing, hardware compatability etc. That's the reason vendor tries to only target the high end smartphones unless promised for which nobody does. Also, now almost half of the market segment is preloaded with Android L for all segments. Like I said, all varies with the vendor. A prominent vendor like Google works very well for providing the updates asap for its devices. P.S. I am writing this on an Android one phone from Google running Android L.
